Our first guest is Joseph Nye, University Distinguished Service Professor at Harvard University, and the author most recently of The Power Game: A Washington Novel.

So one of the more remarkable things about this Security Council voting unanimously for sanctions against North Korea is that the Security Council includes China, which has been a strong ally of North Korea.
And the sanctions include blocking the sale of weapons-related materials, allowing other nations, including China, to inspect incoming cargo.
And perhaps a big oddly, they also banned the sale of luxury goods to the nation.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is headed to South Korea this week.
Now let me - I just have to start with the luxury goods.
Julianne, what's that all about?
It really does speak to, I think implicitly, some of the ways of hitting those in power.
Because obviously this is not a nation that's a wealthy nation, but those in power will directly be affected by the luxury goods.
You know that in the developing world there have been all kinds of questions raised about where foreign aid goes and who gets it and who's corrupt.
And so I mean it's an implicit kind of slap on the wrist.
But you're right, Farai, it's a discordant note in this entire debacle over, you know, who has nuclear weapons, who has a right to have nuclear weapons and, frankly, whether or not sanctions work.
I mean the other sanctions, the other economic sanctions are likely to be far more powerful, so this just seems to be sort of like an underpinning eh, if you will.
Let me follow up with you before I get to everyone else.
Some people have challenged how effective sanctions were in Iraq before the war, the U.S.
war, saying that the people who bore the brunt of the sanctions were children and poor people and so on.
How do you look at sanctions in terms of their effectiveness at reaching the leaders of the nations as opposed to the people in the nations?
Well, we have lots of examples of sanctions really not working and then we have a few examples of sanctions working.
I think that sanctions worked, for example, Farai, in South Africa, when people attempted to make the country ungovernable by dropping investment.
But I think that if we look at Cuba, for example, the poor people, the people who need medication are the people who are hurt.
If we look at Iran and India and Pakistan, we have not seen effective sanctions.
The leaders are free to ignore the sanctions and poor people are the ones who suffer.
We have to develop better responses to display world displeasure, and I'm not sure that sanctions are always the best way.
We like them, we use them, they make a strong point.
But if they don't work, what difference do they make?
Marcelo, what about that, sanctions?
Not a precise science or an art, for that matter.
What we really need is a combination of carrots and sticks.
It's very, very clear that sanctions, unilateral sanctions or even multilateral sanctions by themselves - some exceptions, as we've just heard - don't typically tend to work.

The Connecticut campaign race to the Senate exploded last week after Ned Lamont, who is the official Democratic candidate, received an endorsement from the state's Federation of Black Democratic Clubs.
Nice to join you.
This trend toward the far right in politics has some locals like Taylor Rose excited.
Now that federation questioned Senator Joe Lieberman's support for civil rights in the 1960s.
The senator's camp was outraged.
You know, he's now running as an independent, Senator Lieberman.
And even Lamont's people thought it was a low blow.
On WNPR radio station, Lamont was confronted by one of his own campaign supporters.
(Soundbite of WNPR radio broadcast)
Frankly, I was taken by surprise.
I should've stood up and said at the time that that's unsubstantiated.
It's not part of what I believe.
Your campaign has got to come forward with more than just a press release.
You know, you've got to hammer that home that you disassociate yourself with that.
Well, look.
I take Joe Lieberman at his word regarding his service back in the 1960s.
I disassociate myself from any other comments made, you know, at that press conference.
And in addition of course, Lieberman has been sparring with the Reverend Al Sharpton.
You know, can't we all just get along?
Julianne?
Not at all, not in this one.
The fact is that Henry Parker is a respected civil rights leader who's a former state treasurer of Connecticut.
While I don't think that you can assail Joe Lieberman for his commitment in the 1960s, I certainly think that he can be assailed for his commitment thereafter.
Maxine Waters went up to Connecticut to support Lamont, Al Sharpton and others have, because quite frankly, remember, let's not forget 2000.
Let's not forget that Joe Lieberman was the tepid choice of African-American Democrats for vice president, that indeed he had been shaky on affirmative action and other issues.
He wants to take the moral high ground now, but let's really take a close look at his record.
Yes, he marched with Dr. King.
I'm going to give him props for that.
Yes, he went to Mississippi, and he deserves props for that.
But what has he done after that?
And I think that's it's a legitimate to raise questions about that.
Marcelo, we have a situation now where it looks like Lamont is running slightly behind Lieberman, although the polls change day to day.
How damaging is it to someone who was kind of a, you know, unusual candidate, Ned Lamont, you know, challenging this very established senator to now get into a rift over Lieberman's history?
Well, it's not going to be easy.
He has a difficult battle ahead, and in many ways it's too early to tell.
But Lieberman is coming back, he's leading in the polls and we still have an eternity from now until Election Day.
But my sense is that this will not help the Lamont candidacy.
More sex scandals, more political scandals.
I guess anything could happen.
But before we find out about any of that, Walter, you know, there was some discussion, not just in the black community, of whether America was ready for a Jewish vice president?
The same way when Geraldine Ferraro was running, is America ready for a female vice president?
Do you think that those questions of, you know, sort of ethnic unease get mixed up with the question of what actually is Senator Lieberman's record.
Because he wasn't always in support of affirmative action, and he made that clear?
Well, not necessarily.
I think the problem here is that, you know, many of our elected officials' commitment to civil rights is steeped in nostalgia.
And I think we've had so many politicians who go back to the tried and true, you know, I marched with Dr. King.
And I always said, if everyone who says they marched with Dr. King had actually marched with Dr. King, there wouldn't have been any room on the streets.
I think we have to really kind of look at the reality here.
There were a lot of people who were quote, unquote, "supportive of the civil rights movement.

And I think you can challenge Joe Lieberman on that point.

So while, you know, I think there is some controversy over whether or not the statement is true from a historical perspective, someone needs to be raising the issue of where do you stand today and not allow people to fall back into this comfortable zone of saying, I marched with or, you know, I supported back in 1960, which is now 40 years ago.
So I think, you know, there's still lot of room there in terms of critiquing Joe Lieberman's record on this issue.
